title: Ex-KPMG Partner Gets a Year and a Day in 'Steal the Exam' Scandal
summary: Auditors got advance information from oversight board about which audits would be reviewed. The former No. 2 auditor at KPMG LLP was sentenced to a prison term of one year and one day for his role in a "steal the exam" scandal that exposed serious weaknesses at one of the Big Four accounting firms.

title: Woman Is Convicted of Unlawful Entry at Trump Resort
summary: Yujing Zhang, who was arrested earlier this year, faces sentencing in November. A Chinese woman was convicted Wednesday of unlawfully entering President Trump's Mar-a-Lago resort in Florida, after her arrest earlier this year raised concerns about security at the president's clubs.

title: Uber Vows to Fight California Legislation on Gig Economy
summary: Despite objections from Uber and Lyft, Gov. Gavin Newsom has said he would sign bill to curtail use of contract workers. SACRAMENTO, Calif.-California lawmakers passed landmark employment legislation that challenges the business model of "gig-economy" companies such as ride-hailing giants Uber Technologies Inc. and Lyft Inc. But Uber immediately signaled defiance, saying it didn't plan to change its practices in response to the measure.

title: California Takes Aim at NCAA Pay Ban
summary: College athletes in state could get endorsement deals under bill banning schools from enforcing association's compensation rules. California legislators voted to require schools in the state to allow their athletes to earn endorsement money, setting up a collision with the National Collegiate Athletic Association, which bans compensation for college athletes beyond a scholarship and modest stipend and is threatening to bar California athletes from its competitions.

title: Burglars Are Following You on Facebook
summary: I learned the hard way that social media lets the world know when you're out of town.. When my daughter's wedding drew the family out of town for an extended weekend, I should have realized that my home's security was as fragile as the family's emotions.

title: Progressive Antitrust Paradox
summary: Corporate collusion to build more electric cars gets a Democratic pass.. After news broke Friday that the Justice Department is investigating four car makers for possible collusion, the denunciations were fast and furious. Democrats these days want to use antitrust law against certain corporate targets, but they apparently don't want to investigate if big business is conspiring when it advances their political goals.

title: T. Boone Pickens Jr.
summary: A business champion of free markets and shareholder value.. The colorful capitalists of the 20th century are leaving us, and few were more uproarious than Texas oil man and entrepreneur T. Boone Pickens Jr., who died Wednesday at the age of 91 after a lifetime of bucking the status quo.

title: The World's Dumbest Housing Policy
summary: First California makes homes unaffordable, then it imposes statewide rent control.. If every regulatory instinct Democrats in Sacramento have is wrong and counterproductive, maybe they should take Jerry Seinfeld's advice to George Costanza and do the opposite. Consider a statewide rent cap that Democrats rushed through the legislature this week.

title: The Democrats' Dilemma
summary: A 'normal' candidate might defeat Trump, but beyond Joe Biden, there is no Plan B.. It's too late to turn back now. The 2020 presidential campaign is underway, which means the American people are about to have their second, mass out-of-body political experience.

title: The Only Democrats With a Chance
summary: It's going to be Biden, Warren or Sanders. The rest are fighting over the scraps.. With fall coming on, it already feels as if only former Vice President Joe Biden and Sens. Elizabeth Warren and Bernie Sanders can win the Democratic nomination for president.

title: 'Transaction Man' Review: The Fraying White Collar
summary: There was much to love about corporate life in the 1950s and '60s. Then came the age of buyouts, bailouts and other risky business.. What dominates the left-liberal view of the 1950s, Hilton Kramer observed in the New Criterion in 1993, "is the notion of an entire society in the grip of politically inspired paranoid fear, abject social conformism, empty-headed consumerism, and spiritual sterility." That view has undergone a partial revision over the past 15 years or so. Bernie Sanders often refers wistfully to the '50s, a time when taxes were high, unions were strong and the economy stable. Paul Krugman, in "The Conscience of a Liberal" (2007), called the '50s a "paradise lost." In his latest book, "Beautiful Country Burn Again" (2018), the progressive essayist and novelist Ben Fountain writes approvingly of midcentury America's economic settlement.

title: The Problem With Politics Is the Politicians
summary: They take credit for things they didn't do and avoid accountability for the messes they make.. Pity Joe Biden. He has to convince voters both that the economy was booming less than three years ago, when he and Barack Obama were in charge, and that it's now fallen into such a mess that we need Mr. Biden to come fix it. Whereas Ronald Reagan beat Jimmy Carter in large part by asking voters to consider if they were better off than they were four years ago, Mr. Biden and the seemingly endless list of other candidates running for president would rather voters think about anything but the economy. Democrats want American voters for the next year and a half to be perpetually anxious that the end is imminent but can be staved off at the ballot box.

title: Maryland Worries Fentanyl Drug Sale Could Fuel More Addiction
summary: State lawyers raised 'red flags' around proposed bankruptcy sale of Subsys, the painkiller sold by Insys Therapeutics. The state of Maryland is uncomfortable with Insys Therapeutics Inc.'s proposed sale of the opioid drug Subsys, raising concerns the buyer would fuel further illegal sales of the drug.

title: Be Grateful for Your Health-Insurance Company
summary: It has the thankless job of saying 'no.' But policing claims allows you to get better benefits.. Private health insurers are punching bags of choice in the Democratic presidential primary. "The insurance companies last year alone sucked $23 billion in profits out of the health-care system," Elizabeth Warren fulminated in a June debate. Kamala Harris charged in January that "it is inhumane to make people go through a system where they literally cannot receive the benefit of what medical science has to offer because some insurance company has decided it doesn't meet their bottom line in terms of their profit motivation."

title: Unlocking Arctic Energy Is Vital for Alaska-and America
summary: Congress should proceed with its plan to allow careful oil exploration on the Last Frontier's coast.. This article is signed by Lisa Murkowski, Dan Sullivan and Don Young.

title: Notable & Quotable: Did Russia Decide the Election?
summary: 'I think that really does devalue the people in Wisconsin and Michigan and others who decided to vote for President Trump.'. Condoleezza Rice on NBC's "Today," asked whether Russian meddling swung the 2016 election, Sept. 11:

title: Under Wild Skies Sues National Rifle Association
summary: Lawsuit alleges vendor treated NRA CEO Wayne LaPierre to free hunting safaris. National Rifle Association CEO Wayne LaPierre, his wife and other top NRA officials were treated to free hunting safaris to exotic locales by an NRA vendor, according to a new lawsuit that raises new questions about the organization's governance.

title: Trump Plans to Ban Most Vaping Flavors
summary: FDA will pull mint, menthol and fruity flavors from market, citing health concerns and surge in teen usage. President Trump said the U.S. plans to pull most vaping products from the market, citing growing concerns about health hazards and rising use by teenagers of the trendy alternative to traditional cigarettes.

title: Purdue Pharma Reaches Deal With Cities, 23 States Over Opioid Crisis
summary: Company trying to strike broader deal that includes more states in advance of bankruptcy filing. Purdue Pharma LP has secured support from 23 states and thousands of local governments for a multibillion-dollar deal that could enable the drugmaker to resolve much of the opioid litigation it faces through a planned bankruptcy restructuring, according to people familiar with the matter.

title: Canada's Trudeau Kicks Off Re-Election Bid in Dead Heat
summary: Trudeau's Liberal Party is tied in polls with its main rival, the Conservative Party. OTTAWA-Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau triggered the start of his campaign toward an Oct. 21 election, in which he will try to overcome damage from an ethics scandal and persuade voters to give the Liberal government another term based on the strength of its economic and environmental record.

title: Oracle Co-CEO Mark Hurd Taking Medical Leave
summary: 'Now Mark needs to focus on his health,' said co-CEO Safra Catz. Oracle Corp. said one of its two chief executives, Mark Hurd, will take a medical leave of absence, removing the technology giant's top executive for sales and strategy at a time of intensifying competition in the business-software market.

title: StarKist Hit With $100 Million Fine in Tuna Price-Fixing Case
summary: Justice Department alleged StarKist worked with rivals for almost a two-year period to fix prices for canned tuna. StarKist Co. has been ordered to pay a $100 million penalty for its role in a conspiracy that prosecutors say inflated the prices consumers paid for canned tuna.

title: Weatherford Wins Court Approval for Debt-Cutting Plan
summary: Oil-field-services company's chapter 11 plan gives it a fresh start with more than $6 billion in debt cut from its books. Weatherford International PLC won bankruptcy-court approval of a chapter 11 plan that will slash the oil-field-services giant's debt load by more than $6 billion.

title: Women's Share of Board Seats Rises to 20%
summary: California law requiring female directors causes ripple effects at companies nationwide. One-fifth of seats on a broad swath of public-company boards are now held by women, a sign of change as U.S. corporations face increased pressure to diversify.

title: Bolton Begins Life After Trump With Uncertain Path
summary: Former aides have written books, given paid speeches and one is set to appear on 'Dancing with the Stars'. WASHINGTON-Now that he has been ousted as national security adviser, John Bolton faces the fresh yet well-worn challenge of forging a post-Trump career path.

title: Sneaker Marketplace StockX Seeks New Customers With Bleacher Report Deal
summary: StockX wants to reach fashion enthusiasts beyond its core customer base of sneaker obsessives. Online sneaker marketplace StockX LLC has struck an advertising deal with WarnerMedia's Bleacher Report as it seeks to step up its marketing efforts in an increasingly competitive business.

title: Trump Says Fed Should Reduce Rates to 'Zero, or Less'
summary: Some economists warn president's push might send up long-term Treasury yields, making it harder to achieve goal of locking in low rates. WASHINGTON-President Trump renewed his call for lower interest rates and his criticism of the Federal Reserve on Wednesday, by pressing for the central bank to cut short-term rates to "ZERO, or less," negative rates that the U.S. avoided even after the 2008 financial crisis.

title: Top Official to Depart MTA
summary: Ronnie Hakim plans to leave her post in late November. Ronnie Hakim, one of the New York Metropolitan Transportation Authority's most senior officials, plans to leave her post in late November.

title: U.K. Government Outlines 'Worst-Case Scenario' for No-Deal Brexit
summary: Report describes potential shortages of fuel and medicines, long traffic jams at ports and rising food prices. LONDON-The British government described potential shortages of fuel and medicines, long traffic jams at ports and rising food prices in a report outlining its "reasonable worst-case scenario" if the U.K. left the European Union without a deal to smooth its exit.

title: Top New Jersey Lawmaker Calls for Ban on Vaping Products
summary: Federal officials have urged the public to stop vaping as they investigate the cause of hundreds of potential cases of pulmonary illness. The highest-ranking legislator in New Jersey's Senate wants to ban the sale of vaping devices in the state.

title: For Ken Burns, 'Country Music' Is the Song of America
summary: In a new PBS series, the director of 'The Civil War,' 'Baseball' and other documentaries, portrays America's development through the lens of country music. Ken Burns has made about 30 films over his long career. But his latest documentary, "Country Music," which premieres Sept. 15 on PBS, presented a new set of challenges.

title: We Need to Make Biosimilars Easier to Get
summary: If potential biosimilar manufacturers can't get their product to market, they won't proceed with development.. Regarding Scott Gottlieb's "Don't Give Up on Biosimilars-Congress Can Give Them a Boost" (op-ed, Aug. 26) and Peter B. Bach and Mark Trusheim's "Time to Throw In the Towel on Biosimilars" (op-ed, Aug. 22): Eliminating rebates, which have turned the prescription-drug supply chain into a pay-to-play system, is a better way to create a robust supply of cheap biosimilar therapies than introducing price controls on older biologics.

title: California Defends Its Stance on Glyphosate
summary: California is simply implementing a law that has led to the reduction or removal of toxic substances from products as varied as faucets, children's jewelry, candy, artificial turf and tableware.. Your Sept. 4 editorial "A Scientific Roundup" mischaracterizes the California Office of Environmental Health Hazard Assessment's position on cancer warnings for glyphosate-containing herbicides.

title: Charles Locke: A Good, Unpretentious Man
summary: Charles S. Locke was a self-made man who lived an extraordinary life and gave so much to those fortunate enough to have known him.. Our father, Charles S. Locke, was an unpretentious man who wore a $20 watch and enjoyed spending free time on the porch doing crossword puzzles and reading ("Space Shuttle Disaster Tested Salt Maker's CEO," Obituaries, Aug. 24). The son of a disabled World War I veteran, Dad rose out of poverty in rural Mississippi to manage a Fortune 200 company for nearly 20 years. He bore his frank, down-to-earth Southern style with great pride throughout his life.

title: English Majors Used to Need Language Skills
summary: Woe betide you if you require rewrites or believe they have no talent. Many of the bright kids have figured things out already. The pressure on you is to award an A+ to one and all. If not, out you go.. Regarding William McGurn's "Is Majoring in English Worth It?" (Main Street, Sept. 10): I taught for two years at a state-run university and was appalled to discover that all standards had disappeared. In the sciences at least there is a problem and a solution. In English, particularly in creative writing (where I had the misfortune to be teaching) there is no "solution," only opinion.

title: Regulators Split On MAX Return
summary: Boeing CEO is optimistic jet will return this year, though production cut or pause remains an option. Boeing Co. said Wednesday that the return to service of the 737 MAX jetliner could vary from country to country unless global regulators can agree on a single path to approving software and training changes.

title: Investigators Looking Into Brooklyn Crash That Killed 10-Year-Old
summary: License plate linked to vehicle in fatal collision had been issued four speeding violations since 2017. The car crash that killed a 10-year-old boy standing at a bus stop in Brooklyn is under investigation by the Brooklyn District Attorney's office and the New York Police Department, officials said Wednesday.

title: Gold Rises After Trump Tweet
summary: Precious metal snaps four-day losing streak after president urges Fed to cut borrowing costs. The price of gold rose Wednesday after President Trumprenewed his call for lower interest rates, urging the Federal Reserve to cut borrowing costs below zero.

title: Small-Caps Extend Gains as Growth Worries Recede
summary: Russell 2000 index of small-cap shares posts its third consecutive advance of at least 1% for the first time since January. Small-caps are regaining some of their shine.

title: U.S. Foes May Have More Options After Bolton's Departure
summary: Adviser's tough line meant fewer chances for negotiation; some say that could now change. The ouster of national security adviser John Bolton, one of the most hawkish voices in President Trump's inner circle, has left U.S. adversaries from Iran to Venezuela celebrating his exit and looking for signs of a fresh approach in Washington.

title: North Carolina House GOP Overrides Budget Veto With Few Democrats Present
summary: The Democratic governor had issued the veto, and Democrats called Wednesday's move a legislative ambush. Confusion erupted in North Carolina when Republican lawmakers voted to override the Democratic governor's veto of the state budget with only about half of the members of the state's House of Representatives present.

title: U.S. Stocks Tick Higher As Tech Stocks Rally
summary: Government-bond yields also climb after data show producer prices rose more than expected in August. The Dow Jones Industrial Average notched its sixth consecutive session of gains Wednesday, lifted by a rally among technology shares.

title: Blackstone Raises Largest Ever Real-Estate Fund at $20.5 Billion
summary: Mammoth fund comes even as high returns have gotten tougher late in this real-estate cycle.. Blackstone Group LP has finished raising the largest commercial real-estate fund ever, with $20.5 billion of commitments despite an increasingly tough commercial property market.

title: 'In a New Light: Alice Schille and the American Watercolor Movement' Review: A Pioneer of the Medium
summary: An exhibition revives the reputation of Alice Schille: Once one of the most accomplished and recognized watercolorists in the U.S., she was nearly forgotten by the time of her death.. Columbus, Ohio

title: 'Country Music' Review: A Documentary Makes a Complex Genre Sing
summary: Ken Burns's eight-part, 16-hour series paints tells an expansive, inclusive story of the narrative-driven music.. About six hours and 20 years into the Ken Burns-directed, eight-part "Country Music," Nashville veteran Marty Stuart offers what might be the defining anecdote of the series. "I heard this beautiful story about Charlie Parker," he says, "standing in front of a jukebox in New York City, listening to country records. His buddies were going, 'What're you doing?' And he says, 'It's the stories, man, the stories.'"

title: Islamic State Targets New York City and Police With Online Propaganda
summary: Terror group produces bloody images of police and digitally-faked threatening messages in subways. Islamic State has ramped up threats against New York City and New York Police Department officers in recent weeks, counterterrorism officials said in interviews.

title: Producers, Stars of 'Bones' Settle With Twentieth Century Fox
summary: Studio was told to pay $128.5 million in punitive damages to 'Bones' talent; terms of settlement weren't disclosed. summary: A show of rare and rarely displayed textiles reveals a wide array of influences in the region.. Washington

title: Democrats, GOP Defend Performance in North Carolina Vote
summary: Narrow Republican victory in a district Trump carried by 12 points is a sign that winning the House majority could be difficult. WASHINGTON-Both political parties found something to brag about Wednesday after a hard-fought North Carolina special election, as Republicans celebrated victory in a district they have held for decades and Democrats took the tight race as a sign they could hold onto their House majority in 2020.

title: Photos: T. Boone Pickens Jr., Oilman Known for Unsolicited Takeover Bids

summary: Weakening comes as report shows producer prices unexpectedly rose last month. U.S. government bond prices fell for a third consecutive session after a report showed producer prices unexpectedly rose last month.

title: Immigration Tent Courts Open to Hear Cases, Closed to the Public
summary: Unusual setup aimed at relieving backlogged system deviates from U.S. judicial practices. The government opened tent courts under unusual, closed conditions unlike those of other courts in the country to hear the cases of some immigrants seeking asylum.

title: GameStop Shares Fall as Company Turns to Store Closures
summary: The videogame retailer plans to close between 180 and 200 of its roughly 5,700 stores globally by the end of its 2019 fiscal year. Shares of GameStop Corp. plunged on Wednesday as the embattled videogame retailer turns to closing stores to offset declining sales.

title: Trump Sends Regards to Departed 'Mr. Tough Guy' Bolton
summary: The president wished his ousted national security adviser, John Bolton, well-but only after slamming his views on a range of foreign-policy issues. WASHINGTON-President Trump said Wednesday he is looking at five potential candidates to replace his ousted national security adviser, John Bolton, and wished Mr. Bolton well-but only after slamming his views on a range of foreign-policy issues.

title: Mexican Central Banker Sees Room for More Rate Cuts
summary: Jonathan Heath says Federal Reserve's easing offers 'window of opportunity'. MEXICO CITY-The Bank of Mexico has room to make more interest-rate cuts in coming months if the current downward inflation trend consolidates and the U.S. Federal Reserve remains in easing mode, said deputy governor Jonathan Heath.

title: The Antonio Brown Rape Allegation Presents an Unprecedented Problem for the NFL
summary: The allegations against the Patriots star came in a civil lawsuit, which presents unusual circumstances for the league as it tries to address the situation. Late Tuesday, the phones of New England Patriots and NFL officials began buzzing with troubling news: Antonio Brown had been accused of rape. Quickly, they knew they had to look into the weighty allegations leveled against one of the league's most high-profile players.

title: Young Relatives of 9/11 Victims Carry Legacy in Their Names
summary: Resume Subscription. Gary Shamay never met his uncle who died in the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks on the World Trade Center.

title: Is Sous Vide the New Slow Cooker?
summary: In 'Sous Vide: Better Home Cooking,' chef Hugh Acheson makes an airtight case for the convenience and consistency of a method once limited to restaurant kitchens. These classic fall recipes make it an easy sell. Though it might sound complicated, "sous vide" simply means sealing food in bags and slow-cooking it in a water bath at a precisely controlled temperature, thanks to a gadget called an immersion circulator. In "Sous Vide: Better Home Cooking" (Oct. 15, Clarkson Potter), chef Hugh Acheson advocates adopting this restaurant method at home: "It is a way to efficiently and cleanly make you a better cook, and the often long cook times give you the same freedom that the slow cooker does: the power to walk away from the kitchen and return hours later to a nourishing from-scratch meal." These delicious fall recipes from the book are a great place to start.

title: Children of 9/11
summary: Pain and patriotism in the aftermath of the deadly attack.. A ceremony at the 9/11 Memorial in New York City this morning honored the nearly 3,000 Americans killed in the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11, 2001. It's also a day to remember the people they left behind.

title: American Businesses Say China's Slowdown Is a Greater Threat Than the Trade War
summary: For years, U.S. companies in Shanghai have been steadfastly optimistic about opportunities in China. That's starting to change.. SHANGHAI-American companies are downshifting in China as its economy slows and trade tensions with the U.S. persist, according to a new survey that highlights softening revenue, reduced investment and job cutbacks.

title: China Detains Taiwanese Businessman
summary: Lee Meng-chu is held on national-security grounds after sharing images of Hong Kong protests. A Taiwanese businessman has been detained in southern China on national-security grounds, after he shared images with friends in Taiwan of the antigovernment protests in Hong Kong.

summary: U.S. remains top overall, but it faces a growing threat as China ramps up higher-education spending. The University of Oxford in the U.K. topped a list of the best universities in the world for the fourth straight year, and the California Institute of Technology rose to No. 2.

A concierge ready to advise on the neighborhood's cheapest nachos? A lounge permanently set up for beer pong? Housekeeping you'd best not examine too closely, if my old dorm is at all representative?

title: U.K. Parliament Suspension Is Ruled Unlawful by Scottish Court
summary: The decision will now head to the Supreme Court for a final ruling setting up an unusual showdown. LONDON-Prime Minister Boris Johnson's decision to suspend Parliament for several weeks has been ruled unlawful by Scotland's highest civil court, setting the stage for a rare showdown in the U.K.'s Supreme Court between the government and its opponents.

title: Apple's Stream Won't Drown Rivals

summary: Resume Subscription. FRANKFURT-European auto makers have plowed tens of billions of dollars into developing electric cars and hybrids to comply with stricter restrictions on tailpipe emissions. Now they face the challenge of selling those vehicles.

summary: After nearly 15 years, the deadline to get a REAL ID driver's license is finally approaching; travelers without one will have to use their passports even for domestic flights. summary: 18 years later, young Americans who were born after al Qaeda's assault are starting college and deploying to fight abroad. title: The Rise and Fall of the Front Porch
summary: Once a staple for socializing and keeping cool, the porch has faded in popularity thanks to cars and modern architecture. What happened to the porch?

title: Why WeWork Is Struggling to Sell Its Story to Investors
summary: The shared-office company is having a hard time convincing potential public-market investors it's worth the $47 billion private investors have valued it at. WeWork's parent, We Co., has raised billions of dollars from private investors, including SoftBank Group Corp. at a $47 billion valuation. The shared-office company is having a harder time convincing potential public-market investors it's worth even half that much ahead of a planned initial public offering. Here are some of the issues investors are weighing as they scrutinize the business and growth prospects of We, which declined to comment.

title: Stocks to Watch: GameStop, Dave & Buster's, Roku and More
summary: Resume Subscription. Here are some of the companies with shares expected to trade actively in Wednesday's session. Stock movements noted by ticker reflect movements during regular trading hours.

title: Inside John Pawson's Sleekly Minimalist Cotswolds Home
summary: The pioneering architect who elevated nothingness to an art form has just completed a project in the English countryside for his most demanding client: himself.. If there's a thread that runs through most of John Pawson's work, it is his unwillingness to water down any part of his vision of how things ought to be. Pawson, 70, is a patriarch of minimalism in architecture. For the past 30-odd years he has explored the richness of empty space in stores for Calvin Klein and Jil Sander, hotels for Ian Schrager and various monasteries, churches and museums. But it's mostly on behalf of private clients-Jann Wenner and Fabien Baron, to name two-who believe that, as the old saying goes, simplicity is the ultimate sophistication.

title: Hong Kong Is the Lung Through Which Chinese Banks Breathe
summary: The city's GDP relative to China's keeps shrinking, but that belies its role in the country's banking system. "The naked truth about Hong Kong's future can be summed up in two words: It's over," said Fortune Magazine.

title: Chicken Mansion Redefines Betting the Farm
summary: The estate owned by the late founder of Pilgrim's Pride is headed for auction in East Texas. Talk about a hen house.

title: Introducing Prosus: A Rare European Mega-Tech Stock
summary: Prosus shares soared on their debut, instantly narrowing a valuation gap its parent company Naspers suffered on its massive stake in China's Tencent. Shares in an internet conglomerate that is the largest shareholder in China's Tencent Holdings Ltd. soared Wednesday, after listing its assets under the name Prosus NV in Amsterdam-instantly creating a rare European tech giant.

title: Bolton's Departure Removes a Counterweight to Trump's Foreign Policy
summary: National security adviser's exit makes it more likely Trump will redouble personal diplomacy with Iran and other countries. President Trump has rewritten the U.S. foreign policy playbook with his willingness to meet anyone and go anywhere to get a deal. With his hawkish national security adviser John Bolton gone, Mr. Trump has removed one of the last dissenting voices on his impulses and instincts.

title: PG&E Shouldn't Leave Its Heart in San Francisco
summary: Grappling with wildfires is a shared responsibility, which worsens as good assets are sold. San Francisco's entrance into the fight over PG&E 's scraps may not do anyone, including its own residents, any favors.

title: China's Field of Dreams Attitude to Opening Markets Won't Work
summary: The quotas on western investment into Chinese financial markets are no longer the main limiting factor on inflows. If we open it, they will come. Or so the logic of the Chinese government goes, when it comes to Western investment in its financial markets. That dream is unlikely to become reality.

title: Sonos Can Pump Up the Volume
summary: Embattled speaker maker's stock is hot again, but valuation still leaves room for gains. Hardware companies are hard for investors to love. Sonos has been making that easier lately.

title: Bank Bounce May Not Stick
summary: Bank stocks have rallied on a sharp rebound in interest rates, but banker comments at an investor conference stressed challenges ahead. A leap in Treasury yields has markets behaving as if the worst is over for banks. But lenders still face a number of bad choices at the moment.

title: Investor Hopes for Cheaper Money in Europe Dim
summary: Yields on European government bonds have ticked up as the market pares back expectations for quantitative easing. A month ago, investors were betting the European Central Bank would make a splash. Now they're not so sure.

title: Flooded Missouri River Towns Wrestle With Their Futures
summary: Resume Subscription. WINSLOW, Neb.-Six months after floods submerged this tiny community in eastern Nebraska, many residents want to pick up the entire village and move it to higher ground.

title: Hong Kong Soccer Fans Boo Chinese Anthem-While They Still Can
summary: Display violates terms of a stalled bill to criminalize insults to anthem as protests increasingly direct ire at China. HONG KONG-After pro-democracy protests fizzled out five years ago, fans of the city's soccer team took to booing performances of the Chinese national anthem before international matches. Three years later, Beijing moved to criminalize such unpatriotic behavior.

title: Ground Zero Ceremony Marks 18th Anniversary of 9/11 Attacks
summary: Resume Subscription. NEW YORK-Marjorie Miller returns often to the place where her husband died, now a memorial of black stone and falling water. But it is on the anniversary of his death that she is most drawn to the site where two 110-story towers stood until Sept. 11, 2001.

title: New York City's Income-Inequality Gap Hasn't Changed, Report Says
summary: A conservative think tank's analysis of U.S. Census data shows Mayor Bill de Blasio has made only modest gains in closing disparities. Mayor Bill de Blasio campaigned on a promise to end income inequality in New York City, but a report finds the city has only made modest gains in closing the gap between its richest and poorest residents.

title: Oilman T. Boone Pickens Jr. Dies
summary: A pioneer in hostile takeovers, he made a name for himself with a string of unsolicited bids for larger oil companies. T. Boone Pickens Jr., an oil prospector and pioneer in hostile takeovers whose folksy wit made him one of America's most recognizable business leaders, has died at age 91.

NFL Receiver Antonio Brown Accused of Rape in Lawsuit
summary: Player denies 'each and every allegation,' lawyer says in statement. New England Patriots receiver Antonio Brown, who recently joined the Super Bowl champions after two other teams, has been accused of raping a woman, according to a lawsuit she filed Tuesday.

title: China's Leaders Are Penned In as Citizens Stomach High Pork Prices
summary: Resume Subscription. NANNING, China-Beijing has tried a variety of measures in recent weeks to bump up the pork supply and bring down prices after a yearlong outbreak of African swine fever decimated the country's hogs. So far, they haven't been enough.

title: When My Money and Your Money Becomes Our Money
summary: There are a lot of reasons couples combine their finances-and a lot of reasons it can be difficult. For married couples who seek to combine finances after years of keeping their own accounts, the process is rarely as simple as saying, "I do."

title: What Generation Is Leading the Way in ESG Investing? You'll Be Surprised.
summary: It isn't millennials, the generation that gets most of the attention for driving awareness of ESG issues. Millennials get most of the attention in the world of values-based investing. But growing interest from an older slice of the population-Generation X-and their deeper pockets is helping propel sustainable investing into the mainstream.

title: Ins and Outs of Settling With the IRS
summary: It isn't easy to settle your tax debts for less than you owe, but it is possible. Here is what taxpayers need to know. Here is an idea that probably sounds like a guaranteed waste of time: Ask the Internal Revenue Service to settle your tax debts for less than you owe.

title: One Argument for Radical Income Transparency
summary: Our research suggests that disagreements about government spending may be partly based on misperceptions about how much others make. How much do people actually know about the income and wealth of people who live around them? And how does what they think they know skew the way they think about government taxes and spending?

title: Game Plan: Financial Advice for a Small Farmer Looking to Expand
summary: Jesse Veek left the business world to become a farmer. A financial pro offers advice on how to grow the business and bolster his finances. After studying business in college and working a number of jobs after graduation, Jesse Veek decided office life wasn't for him. So, two years ago, he decided to try his hand at farming, growing crops on 2 acres in Edgerton, Wis., that he leases for $175 a year, per acre.

title: What You Need to Know About Valuing Inherited or Donated Art
summary: Failure to correctly determine the fair market value of inherited or donated art can lead to costly dealings with the IRS. People who inherit artwork, or donate a piece to a museum or other nonprofit face a common goal: Don't run afoul of the Internal Revenue Service.

title: Trump Administration Weighs Action on Homelessness in California
summary: Federal officials visit Los Angeles ahead of president's fundraising swing next week. The Trump administration said it may try to help get homeless people in California off the streets, a move that comes after the president has criticized the state's cities for their handling of the growing problem.

title: How to Make Sense of iPhone 11 and the Other iPhone Choices
summary: Apple's event brought unsurprising hardware tweaks but a few surprising price changes. The result? A trickier decision for those due for an upgrade.. Not much was expected of Apple Inc. (hardware-wise) on Tuesday and, in that respect, it didn't disappoint. The company delivered upgrades to last year's three iPhone models, plus some minor tweaks to the Apple Watch and iPad lines and an update on its coming subscription services.

title: Apple Undercuts Rivals With Streaming Price
summary: Along with trio of iPhones and updated smartwatch, the tech giant set prices for TV+ streaming and Arcade videogame services to help boost sales. CUPERTINO, Calif.- Apple Inc. revealed a trio of upgraded iPhones, including a lower-priced model, and detailed its plans to enter the increasingly competitive video-streaming market with an offering that is cheaper than rivals.

title: Rape Survivor Could Face Fine Over N.Y. Billboards
summary: Kat Sullivan didn't pay the $200 fee to register as a lobbyist, a state watchdog panel says. Kat Sullivan is a rape survivor who says she spent $14,000 on billboards, some of which urged passage of a New York law to give victims of child sex abuse more legal options.

title: Charles Schwab Plans Layoffs as Falling Interest Rates Hurt Profit
summary: The move comes as firms across Wall Street and beyond grapple with a shift in Federal Reserve policy that took some by surprise. Charles Schwab Corp. is cutting about 600 jobs as it deals with the impact of lower interest rates.

title: John Bolton Ousted by Trump as National Security Adviser
summary: 'I disagreed strongly with many of his suggestions,' the president said on Twitter, 'therefore I asked John for his resignation'. WASHINGTON-President Trump dismissed John Bolton, his national security adviser, after a contentious debate about Afghan peace talks became the latest of many disputes over foreign policy that exposed differences so severe that the two men couldn't even agree on how the ouster happened.
